publicwhip.spmotion: *S3M-713 Pauline McNeill: Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi—That the Parliament welcomes the decision of Glasgow’s Lord Provost, Councillor Robert Winter, to recommend Aung San Suu Kyi, the democratically elected leader of Burma who has been under house arrest since 1990, for the Freedom of the City of Glasgow in recognition of her achievements in the service of democracy, as a further signal of Scotland’s support for her immediate release and restoration of Burmese democracy; congratulates Glasgow Women’s Library and Amnesty International Scotland for their successful campaign; calls on all parties and civic organisations in Glasgow to support the Lord Provost’s initiative, and further calls on the Scottish Government to work with the UK Government to highlight the situation in Burma and campaign for an end to oppression. Supported by: John Park*, Elaine Murray*, Robert Brown*, Kenneth Gibson*, Marlyn Glen*, Bill Butler*, Robin Harper*, Liam McArthur*, David Whitton*, Malcolm Chisholm*, Hugh O’Donnell*, Karen Gillon*

S3M-713 Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi (lodged on 29 October 2007) Patricia Ferguson*, Mike Pringle*, Bob Doris*, Mr Frank McAveety*, Trish Godman*, Ken Macintosh*, Jamie Hepburn*, Elaine Smith*, Sandra White*
S3M-713 Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi (lodged on 29 October 2007) George Foulkes*, Bill Aitken*
S3M-713 Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi (lodged on 29 October 2007) Gil Paterson*, Hugh Henry*

S3M-713 Pauline McNeill: Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi—That the Parliament welcomes the decision of Glasgow’s Lord Provost, Councillor Robert Winter, to recommend Aung San Suu Kyi, the democratically elected leader of Burma who has been under house arrest since 1990, for the Freedom of the City of Glasgow in recognition of her achievements in the service of democracy, as a further signal of Scotland’s support for her immediate release and restoration of Burmese democracy; congratulates Glasgow Women’s Library and Amnesty International Scotland for their successful campaign; calls on all parties and civic organisations in Glasgow to support the Lord Provost’s initiative, and further calls on the Scottish Government to work with the UK Government to highlight the situation in Burma and campaign for an end to oppression. Supported by: John Park, Elaine Murray, Robert Brown, Kenneth Gibson, Marlyn Glen, Bill Butler, Robin Harper, Liam McArthur, David Whitton, Malcolm Chisholm, Hugh O’Donnell, Karen Gillon, Patricia Ferguson, Mike Pringle, Bob Doris, Mr Frank McAveety, Trish Godman, Ken Macintosh, Jamie Hepburn, Elaine Smith, Sandra White, George Foulkes, Bill Aitken, Gil Paterson, Hugh Henry
S3M-713 Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi (lodged on 29 October 2007) Marilyn Livingstone*
S3M-713 Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi (lodged on 29 October 2007) Cathy Peattie*
S3M-713 Freedom of the City of Glasgow for Aung San Suu Kyi (lodged on 29 October 2007) Peter Peacock*, Rhoda Grant*
